summary: This is a federal court opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan addressing Ghislaine Maxwell's pretrial motions in her criminal case. The opinion denies most of Maxwell's motions, including her attempt to dismiss the indictment based on Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement, but grants her motion to sever the perjury charges for a separate trial. It also discusses statute of limitations issues for the Mann Act charges. This is a court opinion and order (Document 207) from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell (1:20-cr-00330-AJN). The document denies Maxwell's motion to dismiss the indictment, addressing arguments regarding the statute of limitations, pre-indictment delay, specificity of charges, and legal tenability of perjury counts. It cites the PROTECT Act and Second Circuit precedent to conclude the statute of limitations does not bar prosecution. This is a court opinion and order from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell (Case 1:20-cr-00330-AJN). The document rules on multiple pretrial motions, denying most of Maxwell's motions to dismiss but granting her motion to sever the perjury counts for a separate trial. It also addresses discovery disputes and sets deadlines for further proceedings.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Charged with facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse of minors and perjury. She filed multiple pretrial motions seeking dismissal, suppression of evidence, and severance of charges.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The alleged perpetrator of sexual abuse of minors. Entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida in 2007.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Author of the court opinion and order, presiding over the case in the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Senator Leahy
persons.context: Cited in the legislative history of the PROTECT Act, expressing constitutional concerns about a retroactivity provision.

connections.description: Maxwell is charged as a co-conspirator of Epstein, allegedly facilitating his sexual abuse of minor victims.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and issuing rulings on her motions.

events.title: Epstein enters Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, pleading guilty to state charges in exchange for federal immunity for himself and 'potential co-conspirators' for conduct from 2001-2007.

events.title: Grand jury returns indictment against Maxwell
events.description: A grand jury returned a six-count indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell with facilitating Epstein's sexual abuse of minors from 1994-1997 and perjury.

events.title: Scheduled trial date
events.description: Trial for Ghislaine Maxwell was set to begin on this date.

events.title: Alleged criminal conduct period
events.description: The period during which Maxwell is alleged to have facilitated Epstein's sexual abuse of minor victims, as charged in the S1 superseding indictment.

events.title: Maxwell's civil deposition
events.description: Maxwell gave a deposition in a civil case, which later formed the basis for the perjury charges against her.

events.title: Enactment of the PROTECT Act
events.description: Congress amended 18 U.S.C. ยง 3283 to eliminate the statute of limitations for prosecuting offenses involving the sexual abuse of a minor during the victim's lifetime.

events.title: Maxwell's Deposition in Civil Case
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell gave a deposition in a civil defamation case, which later formed the basis for perjury charges in the criminal indictment.

events.title: Florida Investigation of Epstein
events.description: A police detective in Palm Beach investigated Jeffrey Epstein. Maxwell claims this detective's death prejudices her defense.

events.title: Court Issues Pretrial Rulings
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues an opinion and order denying most of Ghislaine Maxwell's pretrial motions but granting her motion to sever the perjury counts for a separate trial.

events.title: Deadline for Proposals and Show Cause
events.description: The court orders Maxwell to show cause why her grand jury motion should not be dismissed as moot, and orders the parties to submit a joint proposal for a pretrial disclosure schedule.

events.title: Government Produces Discovery Materials
events.description: The Government produced over 20,000 pages of interview notes, reports, and other materials related to non-testifying witnesses.

keyFacts: The court ruled that Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement does not bar the prosecution of Ghislaine Maxwell in the Southern District of New York, as it only bound the Florida office and did not cover the offenses charged (from 1994-1997).
The court granted Maxwell's motion to sever the perjury charges from the Mann Act charges, meaning they will be tried separately.

The court denied Maxwell's motion to dismiss the indictment as untimely, holding that the PROTECT Act's statute of limitations (allowing prosecution during the victim's lifetime) applies to the Mann Act charges involving sexual abuse of minors.

The opinion references a Department of Justice Office of Professional Responsibility report that found the Epstein NPA was 'unusual in many respects' and reflected 'poor judgment,' particularly in its provision immunizing unnamed co-conspirators.

The court concluded that the Mann Act charges in the S1 superseding indictment are sufficiently specific and that Maxwell's other motions to dismiss or strike portions of the indictment were premature or without merit.

The court ruled that the PROTECT Act's amendment to 18 U.S.C. ยง 3283 applies to Maxwell's alleged conduct, meaning there is no statute of limitations bar for prosecuting offenses involving the sexual abuse of a minor during the victim's lifetime.

The court rejected Maxwell's due process claim regarding pre-indictment delay, finding she failed to show the government intentionally delayed for an improper purpose or that the delay seriously prejudiced her defense.
The court found the indictment sufficiently specific, rejecting Maxwell's arguments about vague time periods, non-criminal conduct descriptions, and the omission of victim names.

The court upheld the legal tenability of the perjury charges stemming from Maxwell's civil deposition, finding the questions were not fundamentally ambiguous and issues of materiality and falsity are for the jury.

The document references the death of Jeffrey Epstein, his mother, a police detective, and another individual as potential witnesses, but the court found Maxwell's claims of prejudice from their deaths to be speculative.
The court granted Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to sever the perjury counts from the Mann Act counts, ordering them to be tried separately to ensure a fair trial and protect her right to counsel.

The court denied Maxwell's motion to dismiss the indictment based on Jeffrey Epstein's non-prosecution agreement, as well as motions to dismiss based on statute of limitations, pre-indictment delay, lack of specificity, and legal untenability of the perjury counts.

The court found that trying all counts together would risk unfair prejudice by introducing unrelated allegations of sexual abuse and could disqualify Maxwell's chosen counsel due to their involvement in the prior civil case.
The court denied as premature Maxwell's motions to strike surplusage from the indictment and to dismiss multiplicitous charges, reserving these issues for trial.

The court ordered the parties to negotiate a schedule for all remaining pretrial disclosures, including Brady/Giglio material, Jencks Act material, witness lists, and Rule 404(b) evidence, aiming for production 6-8 weeks before trial.
